item.title: Met PC found guilty of neo-Nazi group membership
item.description: Benjamin Hannam is the first British officer to be convicted of a terrorism offence.

item.title: Derek Chauvin trial: George Floyd's girlfriend tells of first kiss and addiction
item.description: Courteney Ross gives emotional testimony during the fourth day of Derek Chauvin's murder trial.

item.title: Covid: More than a million 'had long Covid in February', and artist's Captain Tom mural
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday evening.

item.title: Lorraine Cox: Man followed and murdered woman on night out
item.description: Azam Mangori, 24, is found guilty of Lorraine Cox's "deeply disturbing" murder.

item.title: Pfizer jab 'stopping 91% of cases in first six months'
item.description: And another study shows even 96-year-olds are producing an impressive immune response.

item.title: Every customer must sign in when pubs reopen
item.description: New rules to help venues reopen outdoors safely this month have sparked anger from industry groups.

item.title: Long Covid: More than a million affected in February, survey suggests
item.description: Official statistics suggest one in five people experience ongoing symptoms five weeks after infection.

item.title: Covid biggest NHS challenge since World War Two, says NHS boss
item.description: Sir Simon Stevens says the pandemic could bring about radical new ways of working.

item.title: Samuel Kasumu: PM's adviser quits amid row over race report
item.description: Samuel Kasumu has been unhappy with the government's stance on race for some time, sources say.

item.title: Jennifer Arcuri: Conservative Party helped PM with inquiry legal bills
item.description: The Tories gave "support" to Boris Johnson in his battle against claims made about his time as London mayor.

item.title: UK weather: Cold and gales forecast amid 'spring swing' in temperature
item.description: After this week's warm temperatures, colder weather over Easter could even bring snow in some areas.

item.title: Lee Collins: Yeovil Town captain dies aged 32
item.description: Lee Collins, defender and captain of National League club Yeovil Town, dies at the age of 32.

item.title: Burgess Hill crash: Car ploughs into house after smashing into lamp-post
item.description: A woman is held on suspicion of drink-driving and criminal damage after the crash in West Sussex.

item.title: Gender balance at festivals: Has it been forgotten in the pandemic?
item.description: There's concern festivals are forgetting about gender balance as they prepare to return.

item.title: April Fools' Day: 10 stories that look like pranks but aren't
item.description: Our round-up of some of the stranger than fiction tales published this April Fools' Day.

item.title: Covid: Will your pet need a coronavirus vaccine?
item.description: Vaccines for animals are being developed, but there is debate over whether they are necessary.

item.title: Captain Sir Tom Moore: Street artist creates Manchester mural
item.description: The tribute has been painted in Manchester by Akse P19 in memory of the 100-year-old Army veteran.

item.title: WWII air raid shelter found in Edinburgh during cupboard clean
item.description: Residents found bunk beds, wartime signage and a reinforced roof in a room under their Edinburgh flats.

item.title: Children dropped over US border wall
item.description: Footage released by US authorities shows alleged smugglers dangling the children over a 14ft wall.

item.title: 'You can't tell victims what racism is'
item.description: What do some young black, Asian and ethnic minority people make of the latest report on race in the UK?

item.title: Tackling sexual abuse in schools through the arts
item.description: The government has set up a helpline and an immediate review into sexual abuse in schools.

item.title: Lockdown: Are people losing skills they're not using?
item.description: Psychologists are studying whether people are losing skills because of lockdown.

item.title: Photographer's exhibition inspired by Birmingham prison inmates
item.description: Edgar Martins' images, inspired by life in HMP Birmingham, aim to challenge conceptions of prison.

item.title: Nicole Thea's husband Global Boga: 'My world has been taken away’
item.description: Afrobeats artist Global Boga speaks out about losing his YouTuber wife and their baby son.

item.title: Sharon Stone's memoir: 5 key moments from The Beauty of Living Twice
item.description: The Hollywood star's autobiography details family abuse, that Basic Instinct scene and health scares.

item.title: Ben Hannam: The neo-Nazi who joined the Metropolitan Police
item.description: Ben Hannam spent his weekends with far-right friends and and kept a photo of himself with a Hitler moustache.

item.title: Batley Grammar School: Blasphemy debate leaves town 'at crossroads'
item.description: People in Batley reflect on the row over pupils being shown a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Mr Brightside: The hit that just won't die
item.description: The Killers' pop anthem has now spent five years in the UK chart. How did it happen?

item.title: Dragons' Den: The hits, misses, and why investments fall through
item.description: Peter Jones and Sara Davies discuss the mechanics of the BBC One show ahead of its 18th series.

item.title: Why April is a big month for your finances
item.description: Lots of changes to household bills, tax and other elements of finances take place in the course of a week.

item.title: Should airports be allowed to expand?
item.description: Climate change: Should aviation be allowed to expand?

item.title: Germany and Namibia: What's the right price to pay for genocide?
item.description: Germany is set to apologise to Namibia for a genocide more than 100 years ago - and to pay an as yet unknown amount of money.

item.title: David Cameron and Greensill: What's it all about?
item.description: Why the former PM is facing calls to be investigated over his links with a controversial financier.

item.title: Race report: What are the key points?
item.description: 'Immigrant optimism' is praised while some anti-racist approaches face criticism by the commission.

item.title: 'I have put everything into my winery'
item.description: South Africa's winemakers hope for a brighter future after a very tough 12 months.

item.title: Mozambique: Why IS is so hard to defeat in Mozambique
item.description: The jihadists appear to be aiming to create their own self-declared "caliphate".

item.title: 118th time lucky? How Man City are battling history to land the quadruple
item.description: There have been more than 100 previous attempts by 15 different English clubs to win the quadruple - will Manchester City become the first to do it?

item.title: Former British Cycling doctor's UK Anti-Doping request probed
item.description: World Anti-Doping Agency examines ex-British Cycling doctor Richard Freeman proposal for athlete biological passport data before Rio Olympics.

item.title: Nathan Baggaley: Olympian tried to smuggle $150m of cocaine
item.description: Kayaking silver-medallist Nathan Baggaley and his brother were found guilty by an Australian court.

item.title: Real captain Ramos out of Champions League ties against Liverpool
item.description: Real Madrid captain Sergio Ramos is set to miss the Champions League quarter-final ties against Liverpool after suffering a calf injury.

item.title: 'Interest in Women's Six Nations is growing and change is happening'
item.description: In her first BBC Sport column of the 2021 Women's Six Nations, England prop Shaunagh Brown talks about the growth of the sport, Grand Slams and jigsaws.

item.title: Chris Ashton: Worcester winger gets six-game suspension for dangerous play
item.description: Worcester's former England winger Chris Ashton is banned for six matches after being found guilty of dangerous play.

item.title: How motorsport's modern-day Spanish explorer plans to change the way we race forever
item.description: In just two days' time a sport kicks off its first event with an aim like no other, at a time like no other.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 31 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: Naga Munchetty: It’s time to talk about race
item.description: Naga Munchetty travelled across the UK to understand what race and racism means today.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
